Brett Neumeier wrote:

> On Thu, 2005-06-02 at 09:06 -0700, Cedric Beust wrote:
>  > It is important to group your tests in various categories, which can
>  > represent several different things depending on your emphasis.  For 
> example,
>  > you can have "database" tests, "front-end" tests, "security" tests, 
> etc...
> 
> I strongly agree, and I think this is something important that is simply
> missing from JUnit.

junit.framework says nothing about how you collect tests to be run. The 
default JUnit test runner makes those decisions, and I agree it's 
annoying the way the current test-collecting behavior is hardwired as 
class-level methods. That said, combine GSBase's "RecursiveTestSuite" or 
JUnit-addons' "DirectorySuiteBuilder" with a filter that examines any 
metadat you want, and you can run any subset of the tests you can imagine.

Agreed, TestNG supports this out of the box, but for every neat feature 
TestNG supports out of the box there will be 20 people crying about this 
other neat feature it doesn't support... it's for that reason that JUnit 
doesn't even try. :)

One big difference between the two is that JUnit assumes that the test 
suite is computed before the first test runs, and I admit that is a 
fundamental and useful difference between JUnit and TestNG. I suppose 
once TestNG has a large user base we'll have a clearer idea how 
important that is. (I know that day is approaching!)

<snip />
> Or you can use marker interfaces to the same purpose:
> 
> public class FooTest implements NeedsDatabaseTest, FunctionalTest { ... }
> 
> and simply have a test collector that finds all of the classes that
> include or exclude particular marker interfaces.  How are annotations
> superior to just using interfaces like that?

You could say that marker annotations are "merely" syntax sugar 
replacing marker interfaces. That said, syntax sugar done well is very 
nice. Also, annotations were /designed/ for this kind of thing, and 
interfaces weren't. Interfaces are not metadata, even if they can be 
metadata. My butter knife can be a screwdriver, but that doesn't mean I 
should avoid buying a screwdriver.
